question_text: A 42-year-old man is evaluated for a chronic pruritic skin rash involving the groin.
question_stem: Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
critique: This patient has tinea cruris (Option D). Tinea cruris is a dermatophyte infection of the groin, pubic region, and thighs, which manifests as an annular lesion with a slight scale, an erythematous, well-demarcated edge, and incomplete central clearing. Tinea can be suspected based on clinical presentation and pruritus; however, diagnosis is based on visualization by microscopic examination of branching hyphae in the keratin (scale) using a potassium hydroxide preparation.
